newsitem.title: UK: IPE Brent closes higher on back of stronger U.S.
newsitem.headline: IPE Brent closes higher on back of stronger U.S.

text.p: IPE Brent crude futures closed firmer on Friday having taken support from stronger U.S heating oil and WTI crude for much of the day.
June Brent closed 22 cents up at $17.91 a barrel.

Brent had achieved a short-lived high of $18.13 a barrel shortly after NYMEX opened, but only comfortably traded 10 cents or so below this in what dealers saw as a corrective bounce after recent price erosion.
"I think there was resistance at $18.05 and $18.10 which it never convincingly broke," said one dealer.
"It basically followed WTI in the afternoon which got some support from good gasoline spread buying," said another.
Further out June Brent resistance was put at $18.23 and $18.50. "The contract has failed four times around $18.49-50," said one analyst.

May WTI, which expires next week April 22, showed determination to break the key psychological barrier of $20.00 a barrel but fell just short with a high of $19.97. It ended the session at $19.85, up 43 cents.
"$20 is definitely a target, but then it needs to breach $20.05 for it to go much further," said one trader who was mildly bullish for gains next week ahead of the expiry.
Gasoline was starting to show tentative signs of a desire to be in the limelight gaining 0.75 to $61.45 cents a gallon.
"Its about time it shouldered some responsibility," said one London trader.
NYMEX heating oil rose 0.40 to 54.40 cents a gallon on the back of colder weather which has tightned supplies.

Earlier, May IPE gas oil ended its session $1.00 a tonne stronger at $163.25 having tracked heating and crude for most of the day. Support was put at $160.00 a tonne and fairly strong resistance at $166.50.
